Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The purpose of this project is to develop a "user's guide" to the present and projected energy resources of our planet and the relationship to climate change. It will prototype and evaluate new ways of providing the public with the information and tools to make wiser choices about powering homes, schools, businesses, and communities.

The project uses a hybrid model of science communication that includes video, in-person presentations, and Web 2.0 social networking. National PBS broadcasts of three hour long programs will reach large audiences influencing the understanding of climate change in measurable ways. Events at four science centers and natural history museums located across the country will explore how increased knowledge of Earth Science informs behavior. The project's social networking tools and resources will motivate and support accessible real-world activities. The multiple PBS broadcasts of the hour long programs over three years could potentially reach an audience of 10 million. Internet users accessing the short videos, authoritative information, and blogs could reach 200,000 to 500,000 per month; the museum visitors attending the live presentations of researchers could reach approximately 80,000-100,000 over the duration of the project.

The core project team includes Richard Alley, chair of the National Academy of Sciences panel on Abrupt Climate Change, who will host the television programs. Andy Revkin, author and science journalist for The New York Times, will be a key project advisor and co-host for some of the television programs. Outreach partners include science centers across the nation and the Society for the Advancement of Chicanos and Native Americans in Science. The project will leverage existing NSF-supported projects such as the Future Earth Initiative led by the Science Museum of Minnesota and ASTC's Communicating Climate Change.

Rockman Et Al will evaluate the project impacts working from front-end to summative stages to understand the reactions of media, online, and on-site users. Proposed project impacts include increasing participants' understanding of how the Earth's system is affected by human uses of energy and the impact of those energy uses on climate. Other impacts include changes in attitude and behavior affecting individual uses of energy. Evaluations will be conducted with TV show viewers as well as science center and website visitors using quasi-experimental, quantitative, and qualitative study designs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
“Earth: The Operators’ Manual” (ETOM) is an NSF-funded initiative developed by Passport To Knowledge (P2K) that takes an apolitical and authoritative approach to both climate change science and clean energy solutions, using multiple informal science education techniques: public television programs, museum outreach events, a project website and social media initiatives.

Three programs, hosted by Richard Alley, a highly-respected geoscientist from Penn State University, were broadcast nationally in primetime on PBS. Program One, “Earth: The Operators’ Manual”, provides clear evidence of manmade climate change, documents the problem of global energy demand and presents several sustainable energy solutions. Program Two, “Powering the Planet”, focuses in-depth on countries (Denmark, Brazil, China, Morocco and Spain) and communities (including Texas) already demonstrating positive approaches. Program Three, “Energy Quest USA”, shows how five very different regions of the United States—the states of Alaska and Kansas, and the cities of Baltimore MD, Fort Worth TX and Portland OR—are implementing solutions to supply clean energy and reduce climate change. Multiple rebroadcasts on PBS stations have reached nearly 4 million nationwide, with more than 250,000 views of the freely accessible videos online. 

Five museum partners facilitated year-long outreach events: Science Museum of Minnesota, Oregon Museum of Science and Industry, Fort Worth Museum of Science and History, North Carolina Museum of Natural Science, and the Reuben H. Fleet Science Center in San Diego. Events included program screenings with panels of local experts, spoken word presentations by national figures including military officers describing the Pentagon’s sustainability initiatives, and Science Cafes and outdoor festivals. A program taped during Alley’s presentation at the Science Museum of Minnesota, “Adventures of a Climate Scientist,” has been re-aired both state-wide and regionally.

The ETOM website, launched in April 2011 and updated in 2012, contains closed captioned videos of the full programs, each of which are also available in short “chapters” and free for download by educators. EarthTheOperatorsManual.com also offers web-exclusive video clips, quizzes, widgets with interactive energy-saving tips, links to ETOM resources and additional climate change and sustainable energy content. ETOM’s Facebook posts have included news, provocative quotes and statistics, and inspiring examples of sustainable energy initiatives. The page has secured an unusually high level of “Engagement” as measured by the number of Comments and Shares.

ETOM content has also been widely presented at public and professional venues including annual AGU meetings in 2011-2014, a national SACNAS conference (Society for the Advancement of Chicano and Native American Scientists), church gatherings and educational conferences. ETOM’s unique approach was favorably cited by articles in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences and other publications. NASA, NOAA and the interagency CLEAN collection of peer-reviewed classroom resources all link to ETOM, and several segments are also accessible via the Department of Energy-supported National Geographic Society’s CONNECT site. A chapter in Springer Verlag’s tradebook on innovative approaches in Earth science outreach focuses on the project.

ETOM collaborated with Coursera and Penn State making the videos and other content part of an experimental MOOC (Massive Open Online Course) that debuted in January 2014.
